characters: EXT. CITY STREETS/INT. EDDY'S JEEP NIGHT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A woman's hands descend to the keyboard of an organ, playing the opening chords to a duet from the Bach Cantata #78.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: the choral conductor, summoning forth the sound of two women's voices singing the text.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Wir eilen mit schwachen doch emsigen Schritten, O Jesu, O Meister...' (etc)

dialogues.speaker: HELEN DEXTRA
dialogues.text: The latter on crutches, a cast on her leg. They stand center stage, their texts resting on music stands. Seated off to the side, are two male soloists (VINCENT GALLARDO & KENNETH DOWLER). Behind them a chorus of men and women, waiting, as:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He begins to sing aggressively over the duet. He suddenly drops his hands to his side. The organist discontinues and the voices of the soloists trail off:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Spruance, would you like to show me where it's marked smearing here... (hitting at the score)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... because I swear, I don't see it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry.   I didn't know I was.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Also, I'd be mildly content if I could have a little less delirious self-appreciation and some small regard for remaining somewhere in the vicinity of the goddamned note.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MAN TROUBLE - Rev. 4/23/91                            2.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: He returns his attention to the score. While Joan grumbles to Helen, a late arriving member of the chorus (EDDY REVERE) can be seen taking his seat amongst the others:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wasn't smearing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sssh, come on now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I'm telling you, this is personally motivated. Since I moved out he's been doing this, making remarks and being... incredibly pricklike...                           *

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now, if our lovely soprano would like to stop grumbling for a moment, I'd like to take it once again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (under her breath)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: See what I mean?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pardon me? JOAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I said fine, let's do it again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with a cold stare)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From the beginning please. He signals a down beat and they resume somewhere near the top of the duet.

dialogues.speaker: WATANABE BLISS
dialogues.text: She speaks emotionally, hoping to solicit sympathy: ADELE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He never says, 'Honey I love you, you're doing a great job.' I don't feel he respects me as a person and I'm just not that happy with the stature of our relationship.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uhm hmm.   I hear you.

dialogues.speaker: ON POST-GRADUATE MFCC THERAPIST
dialogues.text: seated behind a desk in a large deserted classroom:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now I want you to look at Harry and tell him how you feel. She turns her gaze to EUGENE EARL AXLINE, alias HARRY BLISS. He sits in an adjacent chair, an abject hostage. Discomforted by her flinty stare, he glances away, to the window where the faint sounds of the CHORAL REHEARSAL can be heard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I feel like he's not plugged into my needs, and I'm not getting enough positive feedback... Harry shakes his head, shifting about uncomfortably.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: See, look at him shaking his head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, let's see what he wants to say here. Harry, how do you feel when she brings out this material?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How do I feel? I feel she just overheats on every little side issue, and when I go to try and communicate with the woman, for some unknown reason she doesn't believe a damn thing I say.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh that's a lie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: See what I mean?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, you know what this whole thing hinges from? He came to rent a building from me which is now his place of business...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So what, he's not interested in that, that's not what he's asking. (to Therapist)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: See what she does? She wants to dig up and haul out miscellaneous things that's got nothing to do with this. I mean, I agreed to come here, okay, but I have to tell you, Iwo Jima's got a lot of faulty notions in her head about me that....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alright, there. Right now. That's another thing I want to interject...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pardon me, I was making a statement here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, let's try and hear each other out if we can. Go on, Harry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I forgot the upshot of what I was saying, but...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, this syndrome where I've asked him to address me by my given name and he just goes on ignoring my wishes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alright. Look at him and really tell him how you feel about that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't want you to ever call me Iwo Jima again!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's a legitimate request, isn't it? Harry begrudges a slight nod.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you can't call me Adele, don't call me anything at all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MAN TROUBLE - Rev. 4/23/91                             5.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So? Can you look at Iwo Jima, Harry, and tell her... She darts a confused frown at the Therapist.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Better yet, can you take her by the hand and say, 'I hear what you're saying'? Reluctantly, he reaches over and takes her hand, mumbling something which though indistinct, causes Adele's features to pucker with emotion and brings her to the edge of tears.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good.  That's good... because there's a lot of love here, isn't there.  (stealing a quick look                     * at his watch)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A poster outside the building announces a future engagement of THE LEWIS DUART MASTER CHORALE. (SEE Appendix) Joan comes out the door and moves down the steps to a campus walkway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joan, walking quickly across the campus.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joan, moving with nervous alert, approaches a Mercedes sedan parked next to an Econoline van. Placing her key in the lock, she notes a flyer on her windshield. She removes it, glancing briefly at this heading in bold type: WOMEN - DON'T LIVE IN FEAR. A low RUMBLING sound causes her to lift her gaze over the top of the car, where an attack shepherd (DUKE), slowly unsheathes his teeth and fixes her with a threatening stare through the closed window of the van. Her eyes drop down to the legend on its door panel: House of Bliss Shepherds - Peace of mind - Twenty-Four Hours A Day - Call 7-A-T-T-A-C-K. MAN TROUBLE - Rev. 4/22/91                             6.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harry and Adele moving toward the parking structure:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Next time I want to bring out some of our sexual hot spots.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The hell you are, honey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The hell I'm not.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Harry and Adele approach the passenger door of the van:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... at fifty bucks a shot, out a my pocket... (unlocking the door)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm going to listen to some pencil-necked butthead tell me I don't know how to relate to you...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Daddy, do you want this marriage to work or not.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hear  you, honey. But let's have just a  little more trust on your end of  this thing, okay? That's all I ask. (opens the door)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A bus stop poster advertising a current knife-kill movie entitled Blood and Kisses. A woman in jeopardy, with the obligatory expression of helpless terror on her face, flees from a menacing male figure wielding a bloodied knife.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joan is stopped at a signal, frowning up at the malevo- lent message on the bus stop poster. The light changes. A CAR HORN breaks her disturbed reverie and she proceeds through the intersection. MAN TROUBLE - Rev. 5/3/91                           7.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FOLLOWING WITH Joan as she enters the foyer and moves along a first floor hallway to her apartment. She turns her key in the lock, opens the door, then steps OUT OF VIEW.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joan stands briefly in the dark, apprehending something untoward. She reaches to a wall switch, turns on the lights and sees: The living room has been completely savaged. Pictures have been pulled from the walls, books have been swept from the shelves, chairs are upended and area rugs lie rumpled and dislocated. A vase of flowers atop a grand piano is overturned and water from it stains the polished surface. Her gaze moves to a bank of windows overlooking a garden patio. The glass pane in one of them is broken and the window stands partly open. ON Joan's stunned reaction as she fearfully scans the room. Then she suddenly reaches to the front door, opens it and disappears into the hallway, shutting the door after her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A detective (MELVENOS) moves about, glancing at the devastation. Joan, seated on a couch, addresses him: (In the b.g., Helen Dextra stands on her crutches near th piano, and beyond her a FINGERPRINTER dusts for prints around the frame of the broken window.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You sure nothing of value has been removed from the dwelling?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, nothing. That's what's so disturbing. I mean, why would someone do something like this...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MAN TROUBLE - Rev. 5/3/91                               8

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, you have quite a nice little                   * mess here. (poking his toe at some debris on the floor) It kinda looks like somebody doesn't like you, doesn't it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you mean, somebody doesn't like me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Fingerprinter interrupts:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not much on the window. A few partials and a bunch of smears.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Check out the bedroom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As he moves to the hallway leading to the bedroom:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You think this is someone I know?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's explore that. Have you had any recent trouble with anyone?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Helen hobbles INTO VIEW, seating herself in a nearby chair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MAN TROUBLE - Rev. 4/23/91

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anyone whose displeasure you might've incurred in some way?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now thoroughly paranoid, she frowns down at the carpet, scanning her memory for the commission of some past offense.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For instance, just the other day we had a homicide concerning a dispute over a parking space.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who could it be?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're not married, I take it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Her mind is still off searching for enemies and she fails to respond:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's in the process of a divorce.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about him? He's our conductor, he's an artist and not someone who'd ever...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You mean Lewie? He'd never do anything like this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shrugs) You never know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is a light knock at the partially opened front door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello?   Anybody home?

dialogues.speaker: ON ATTRACTIVE RED-HAIRED WOMAN, (ANTONIA "ANDY" ELLERMAN)
dialogues.text: stepping into the room:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi, Joanie...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MAN TROUBLE - Rev. 4/23/91

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (under her breath) Oh great.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just got in from Hawaii and thought I'd drop by for a minute. (glancing about) What the heck happened in here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excuse me, it's my sister...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (not interested) Uhm hmm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Joan gets up and moves over to Andy, he glances at his watch and exits to the bedroom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Andy, this is not the most opportune time. I happen to have had a burglary in here last night...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh really?   That's awful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So could I just call you later?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, can't you give   me one minute? I'd like to    know if you got the manuscript I   sent you. (squinting at   Helen) Who's that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Helen Dextra, you've met her before.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, I have? (then quickly to Joan) Anyway, did you read it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Read what? I don't know what you're talking about.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MAN TROUBLE - Rev. 4/23/91

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm talking about the book I've written about Red and me, that I sent you a copy of, is that so hard to follow?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh no. You've written a book about Red Layls.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not just about him, Joanie, he's only one of many episodes in my life, you know that. Have you got a Perrier?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I don't. Let me just call you at home later.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not going to be home. I'm checking into a hospital to have a bone spur removed from my foot. Then I'm going to New York, to meet with a top publisher... (lowering her voice) ... which, incidentally, I would not care for Mr. Redmon, fecal- face Layls to know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Melvenos and the Fingerprinter re-enter:

dialogues.speaker: ANDY MELVENOS
dialogues.text: You know what he said to me?        We're going to be lea

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait, I need to talk to you...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Melvenos and the Fingerprinter step out into the hallway, with Joan following:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wanted to ask you, if there's somebody, who for some unknown reason, doesn't like me, what do you suggest I do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MAN TROUBLE - Rev. 4/23/91                             12

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I might put some bars on the windows. (giving her his card) My name's Melveny, if you want to get in touch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Really though, I don't see how this could be somebody I know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe not.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They start down the hallway and Joan addresses their backs:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because I actually go miles out of my way to avoid conflictual situations.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Helen, now captive to Andy's epic, is seated next to her on the couch, attempting to listen politely to a tale without an end:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And to top it off, my lawyer said, 'Don't worry, they're just pissing into the wind...' HELEN                         ANDY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uhm-hmm.                      And I said, they're pissing into the wind but it's blowing back in my face...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joan has reentered the room and approaches them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Some help I'm going to get from him, because he's scared to death of Red.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Andy, are you telling me the truth?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MAN TROUBLE - Rev. 5/3/91                               1

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (turning to Joan) Yes, he's afraid, they're all afraid, they're all off skiing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Speaking of lawyers... (tapping on her cast)                                         * One fell on me while I was                            * sunbathing.                                           *

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I mean, are you really going to New York?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, I'm going to New York, where I intend to remain in semi-private seclusion, at an undisclosed...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well maybe I could stay at your house while you're gone. So could you tell your housekeeper to...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait, I just want you to hear what this colosal shit said about me, through his great white shark of a lawyer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pardon me, but I don't care what he said. My apartment, as you can                     * see, is a complete shambles, I have                   * a terrible headache, I've been                        * informed that somebody doesn't like me, and I really don't want to stay here by myself!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fine, why don't you take my house then?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joan sinks down into a chair, exhausted:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gee whiz, why make such a big deal out of everything?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MAN TROUBLE - Rev. 4/23/91                              1

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Helen) I just got off a plane that almost fell into the Pacific Ocean like a piece of rotten fruit... (to Joan) ... but did I mention it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Duke lies on the floor, watching Harry. He stands at a cork board on the wall behind his desk, adding a clipping announcing the Fourth Victim of a local serial killer called the Westside Slasher, to an assortment of other items on violent crimes. As he does: JUNE HUFF, enters from a door of the rear of the office. Moving past Harry's desk, she picks up a folded newspaper page, continues to an upholstered bench beneath a window, lies down and begins reading.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (moving to his desk) Now don't start lazing around, June. Let's get with it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (under her breath) You get with it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He sits down at his desk and begins going through his drawers, looking for something. She lowers the paper and looks over at him:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you like my hair this way, or do you like it straight?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's very nice, Sluggo.   Go hose out the kennel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She goes back to reading.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where the hell are my nail clippers?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The PHONE on his desk begins to RING:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I told everybody to stay out of these drawers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MAN TROUBLE - Rev. 4/23/91                             15

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (reading the paper) I think I'll go down to the Amazon, and get involved with the trees.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get this first, will you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She gets up and moves over to the desk:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They need people, because that hole is getting...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (cutting her off) Remember, don't say I'm here 'til you find out who it is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She picks up the receiver and speaks into it:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah?... I doubt that he's here at this present time... Yeah, maybe later today sometime... Who are you addressing? Uh, the executive kennel maid... uh-huh. Yeah. Okay, I'll tell him... So long.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She hangs up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah?   Who was it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ferde at something Motors. He wants two payments by tomorrow or he's gonna come an' repop the van.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bastard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He goes back to reading. June returns to the bench, lies down again and starts grumbling:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know, you said you were going to get me a little Honda Elite to tool around in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MAN TROUBLE - Rev. 4/23/91

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't give me a bad time, lard. I've got enough trouble with Iwo Jima and her complaints, alright? Now the woman doesn't even believe you're my niece.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I'm not.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's not the point I'm making.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suddenly irritated, he begins fumbling through a pile of bills on top of the desk:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know   what's gonna happen if I can't pay   these damn breeders and get some   adult dogs on the premises?    Pretty damn quick, some asses are   going to hit the pavement,   believe me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So?    I'm sick of dog turds anyway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He scowls at her, then looks out the window:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesus, here   I am, sitting in the center of a   lot of wealth, the escalation   in crime couldn't be better, and   I'm not turning a damn nickel   on it...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He catches sight of something outside:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh shit.    There's Lee.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Across the street, a van not unlike Harry's can be seen. On the sidewalk beyond it, a man (LEE) stands putting coins in a parking meter.

dialogues.speaker: ON HARRY
dialogues.text: Moving quickly into the doorway to the reception area:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MAN TROUBLE - Rev. 4/23/91

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm in Vegas, delivering a couple a dogs to Wayne Newton. (to the dog) Duke, Fuss'! (to June) You don't know when to expect me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He and the dog disappear FROM VIEW.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joan is seated at the piano, playing Ravel's "Reverie." She breaks off as she sees a dark young man (BALTO) move past the living room window. She resumes playing until her attention is once again drawn to the window, where a middle-aged Hispanic woman SOCORRO moves past in the opposite direction with a young man, who now carries a suitcase. She rises and crosses to the windows to see them get into a gaudy low-rider and begin backing down th driveway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joan hurries out of the house and runs down the drive- way toward the low-rider calling out:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Socorro!! Wait a minute!   I want to talk to you!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Low-Rider comes to a stop. Joan approaches the pas- senger window and leans down to Socorro:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excuse me, Socorro, but do you mind if I ask what's happening, why are you leaving?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No se, lo siento.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm asking, where-are-you-going?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (indicating Balto) Esto me yerno, Balthazar. You speak please Balto para mi.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MAN TROUBLE - Rev. 4/23/91                              1

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, what's going on, are you bringing her back later or what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, Monday I bring her back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Monday? But this is Thursday, I can't stay here alone 'til Monday.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN SOCORRO
dialogues.text: It's my understanding            Si, lunes, lunes. that Socorro lived here, otherwise, I would've made other plans.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, but she got her time off, too, man, you know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joan straightens up, sighing angrily and looking up at the house:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, this is just glorious.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The low-rider moves down the driveway and as it disap- pears onto the street, Joan moves to an electric box atop a metal column at the edge of the driveway. She presses the button and looks at the gates. They remain open. She steps over to the gates and tries to close them manually. The locking device fails to engage and a portion of it falls off into the bushes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As she leans   down to look for the fallen part,   a pick truck can be   seen parked down the street. The    back o driver's head   (BUTCH GABLE) can be seen and on   the si panel of the   truck are the words "Canyon Tree   Surgeon

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Giving up on the gates, Joan turns and moves with evident reluctance up the driveway, passing a three-car garage in which her Mercedes and another car hidden under a trap ca be seen. MAN TROUBLE - Rev. 4/23/91                           19.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TRAILER MUSIC. Joan is asleep on the bed. Lying beside her is a fireplace poker and a mallet meat tenderizer. Across the dark room, a trailer of Blood and Kisses plays on the TV screen. The scantily-clad woman previously seen on the bus stop poster backs away from a steadily- stalking camera. Her eyes widen in the familiar expression of helpless terror and as she opens her mouth to scream: Joan flinches and sits up. She turns the TV OFF, which descends into a wooden console. At that moment, there is a VOICE from outside the bedroom window: BUTCH                                    *

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, Andy!                                             * In the vicinity of the bedroom window, a man in work clothes can be seen pounding on the glass as he continues yelling: BUTCH (CONT'D)                           *

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's Butch! Get your ass in gear                       * and say hello to your old drinking buddy! She calls loudly out to him: JOAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Andy's not here! He moves to the glass facade and peers inside, looking for the source of the voice: BUTCH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, who are you, honey? JOAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's out of town, and there happens to be several other people in here trying to sleep, so... BUTCH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whyn't you come out and say hello? JOAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will you please go away!? BUTCH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, stick your head out the door an' let's see what you look like.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MAN TROUBLE - Rev. 4/23/91                              2

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, but if you don't leave, I'm going to call the Foothill Patrol.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, fuck you, honey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He cups a hand over his crotch and, sticking his tongue out, flicks it in an obscene manner across his lips.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tch, where does she find these                         * people.                                                *

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was just trying to be nice. (moving backwards to the flower bed) Go ahead an' call 'em, bitch, I don't give a shit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He leans down, picks up a dirt clod from the flower bed and throws it toward the window:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll just come back and kick your ass in for you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joan moves along the windows with her weapons in hand, watching as Butch wavers erratically up to the driveway where the previously seen pickup can be seen. She waits until he gets in and drives off, then she moves back into the bedroom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joan, pacing about in nervous distress. She stops abruptly, throws her weapons onto the bed and moves purposively to her handbag. Rummaging through it, she finds the House of Bliss flyer, unfolds it and looks at the reassuring photograph of Harry and Duke.

dialogues.speaker: DUKE
dialogues.text: Posed in an alert stance, Duke breaks into a run, loping gracefully across the lawn to Harry, where he assumes a sitting position upon the command:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MAN TROUBLE - Rev. 4/23/91                              2

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Duke, platz! (to Joan) Always the name first, and then the command.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She stands off to the side, repeating the command and studiously writing it down in a small notebook.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now, in regard to any   aggressor seeking to give you a   bad time, I want to show you what   you can expect from a dog of   this caliber.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He takes hold of the dog's muzzle, lifting the lips to reveal the large scimitar-like canines:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here we have the dog's arsenal, so to speak. The animal is trained to apply pressure to specific points of the body until the bone is more or less crushed. (releasing the muzzle) If the attacker is bearing a weapon of any kind, be it a gun, a club, a knife or what-have-you, the dog will, excuse me for saying... ("politely" indicating his crotch) ... automatically go for the testicles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh god, what if I don't want him to do that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You want him to do that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I just want him to scare someone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Believe   me, this will scare them, as well   as incapacitate their mind and any   ability to maneuver against   you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know, I have an extremely sensitive reaction to dog dander, so maybe I shouldn't...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let me ask you something. I like to get a general picture of the individual situation I'm working with.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MAN TROUBLE - Rev. 4/23/91

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: He pauses to light a cigarette, making a quick, reflexive appraisal of her contours as he does:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you married, single, living alone or with some other party?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm in the process of a divorce and I moved up here because my apartment was burglarized and... (suddenly mistrustful) But I'm not entirely alone, there's a housekeeper here, and several friends.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, the hills are hit heaven as far as burglaries go. And right up on Mulholland is where they found the fifth victim of the Westside Slasher...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, please, don't tell me about that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Believe me, I know what you're up against, being an attractive, and I take it, unattached woman, such as you are... (flicking his cigarettte away)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But we're going to remedy that situation right now, and get you to feeling as safe as a little baby, alright? (indicating her notebook)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What've we got there so far?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (reading her notes) Ober, platz, geh am platz, bringen, komm, sitz, fuss', fahrt and blieb.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MAN TROUBLE - Rev. 4/22/91

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, that's enough for a start on the basic control commands...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He scans the grounds for signs of something we as yet know nothing of:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now let's do a little work with the assailant.

dialogues.speaker: HARRY
dialogues.text: She holds Duke on a short lead, and as they move along a wooded area of the grounds, he leans in close, directing her in confidential tones:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alright now, Joan, give him the command, 'Duke, wachen sie.'

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Duke, wachen sie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good.   The dog is now on alert.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As they walk, Harry glances about, impressed with the appearance of wealth inherent in the house and grounds:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is really a nice piece of real estate you've got here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (tense and distracted) It's not mine, it's my sister's.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, it's your sister's. (pause) And where's she?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looking down at Duke) Am I doing this right? Shouldn't I be prepared for something?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Never look at your dog.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MAN TROUBLE - Rev. 4/29/91

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Never look at your dog?    Okay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They move forward a few feet, when Harry, now slightly behind Joan, makes a covert hand signal in the direction of some trees several yards ahead of them. June, in a padded attack suit, suddenly jumps out from behind the trees, assuming an aggressive stance and emitting a repertory of menacing sounds. JOAN                       HARRY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh my God!                               Duke, fasse! Duke responds immediately, lunging toward June, pulling Joan along with him. June screams and starts to run away. Harry moves after Joan, yelling ahead to June:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dammit, June, don't exhibit fear until I tell you!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Seeing the dog still in pursuit, June ignores the command and as Duke continues to tow Joan behind him:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get him under control now, Joan.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am... (struggling with Duke) Good boy, be nice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Give him the off command!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I forgot it!     You tell him!   Duke, stop!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He hurries up behind her, grabbing her around the waist to anchor her and addressing the dog:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Duke, aus!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The dog instantly assumes a sitting position. Joan, out of breath and exhilarated with fear and excitement, turns to Harry:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MAN TROUBLE - Rev. 4/29/91                              2

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My golly, that was incredible. I                      * love this dog. Did you see that?                      * I can't believe how strong he is.                     * I felt like a rag doll...                             *

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What did I tell you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: at the desk making out a check while Harry, in the b.g., takes in a series of photographs on the den wall of some of the highlights in the life of Andy Ellerman. (See Appendix)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ordinarily I wouldn't do this, even on a temporary rental basis, because he's the absolute top security and attack dog in the country.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She lays the pen aside, studying him with evident interest as he looks at a photograph of Andy and a man on a hunting safari in Africa.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is this your sister?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, that's her, with her third husband, Eric Ellerman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uhm hmm. (moving to another photograph) Wait a minute, who's this guy, isn't this Red Layls?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No kidding. Your sister's involved with Red Layls? This guy's gotta be one of the five or ten richest men in the country, with business connections all over the place.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MAN TROUBLE - Rev. 4/22/91                            26.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Feeling slighted, she watches him move to a picture of Andy descending the steps of a plane with Layls watching her on the tarmac.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And she's your sister. That's amazing. I mean, this is an individual I'd really like to meet sometime.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He leans in close to a photograph of Andy in a bikini.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Boy, look at that figure. I have to say, your sister is really an attractive looking woman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, that's quite a compliment. I'll have to pass it on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: June, in the b.g., still in the attack jacket, leaning sullenly against the van and watching Harry work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll skip back up in a day or two, okay, just to see how you're doing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And Joan, I want you to know, it's been a great pleasure doing business with you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh well... (her gaze flits shyly away) ... thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Feel free to call on me for anything. Anytime of the night or day, 24 hours.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And would you also thank your...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As she gestures toward June, Harry takes hold of her hand, looking earnestly at her:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I sincerely mean that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: as Harry unzips the attack jacket:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You big flirt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, dumpty, don't start that. (removing the jacket) This is quality clientele. It calls for a certain kind of approach. (nods toward the house) Just soak some of this in, will you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He steps past her and goes to the van:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (giving him the finger) Soak this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As he opens the back panel:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Start to pattern yourself. Breed up. (tossing the jacket inside the van) Observe the woman, for Christ sakes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh screw her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He closes the back panel and as he moves past her:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't screw this type of individual.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You would.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On his way to the driver's door:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is the kind of atmosphere we want to gravitate toward. (opening the door) Did she even ask me the cost? (as he gets inside) Dammit, I really respect that.

dialogues.speaker: ON JUNE
dialogues.text: grumbling as she moves to the passenger door:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well I don't, he isn't even your dog.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joan, her mood light-hearted, enters, with Duke following. She crosses to the closet, selects a change of clothes and moves to lay them out on the bed. Noting the message light blinking on her answering machine, she steps over to the night-stand, presses the playback and to a series of TONES preceding the recorded messages, MOVES OUT OF FRAME.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The indistinct sounds of a TAPED MESSAGE OVER: Joan turns the tap on in the wash basin and begins splashing water on her face. Then as she reaches to a towel and turns the tap off, the WORDS of a popular ROCK SONG can be heard. Exhibiting some curiosity, she exits the bathroom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joan stands holding the towel over her   mouth, staring down at the answering machine. Issuing    from it, a MAN' VOICE in an eerily whispered falsetto,   singing the word "Every breath you take, Every move you   make, I'll be watching you." MAN TROUBLE - Rev. 5/20/91                           29.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (ABOVE MUSIC FAINTLY OVER:) Once again Joan is stopped at a signal. Aware of someone watching her, she turns to look through the window. A MAN in an adjacent car is staring at her, and momentarily addresses her with a peculiar request:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How about a little smile. She quickly faces front and as the light changes, accelerates through the intersecion.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (SHOT 5/16)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Conducting the soprano section of the "Et Resurrexit," accompanied by the pianist.

dialogues.speaker: ON REST OF CHORALE
dialogues.text: The previously seen Eddy Revere among them.

dialogues.speaker: ON JOAN AND OTHER SOLOISTS
dialogues.text: Seated on a lower level of the tiered chairs arranged in a semi-circle around Lewie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Her eyes fixed on Lewie intensely perusing him for any signs of malevolence.

dialogues.speaker: LEWIE
dialogues.text: As he addresses the sopranos over their voices.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is supposed to sound virginal, ladies, so let's try to fake it.

dialogues.speaker: ON SOPRANO CHORUS
dialogues.text: singing and their various reactions to the above remark. MAN TROUBLE - Rev. 5/20/91                            30.

dialogues.speaker: ON DUKE
dialogues.text: He lies on the lawn, secured to the base of a tree by a long leash. Eddy moves INTO VIEW and stepping over to Duke, leans down as though he intends to pet him:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't do that. He turns to see Joan approaching with a paper cup filled with water.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't do what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're not supposed to look him straight in the eye.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have a dog you can't look in the eye, Joan?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's not just a dog. He's a Schutzhund trained attack dog.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh... He steps back from the dog as Joan leans down to give Duke some water from the cup.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was told to avoid a direct gaze and always look at the base of the right or the left ear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't have to go to all this trouble, I've offered to stay up at your sister's with you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't tell you how mad I am at Lewie, that I have to leave him out here, tied to a tree...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: God, you're stubborn, Joan.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MAN TROUBLE - Rev. 5/20/91                          30A.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not stubborn, I'm so accommodating, it's sickening.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She pats Duke on the head and stands up:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But you won't tell me what's really bothering you. Why don't you confide in me anymore?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No you don't. Come on, talk to me. Let's go have a drink after rehearsal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (reluctantly) Tonight?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A WOMAN chorus member sticks her head out the stage door:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eddy, you better come, he's rehearsing the tenors!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm coming...! (then to Joan) How about tomorrow night then?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know.    Let's say maybe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (slightly annoyed) Well don't go out of your way, Joan.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He moves quickly toward the rehearsal room. Immediately afraid of his displeasure, she calls after him:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eddy?   Tomorrow's fine.   Okay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Before disappearing into the studio, he makes a gesture acknowledging her capitulation.

dialogues.speaker: OMITTED
dialogues.text: & 35 )J(   MAN TROUBLE - Rev. 5/21/91

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harry, Joan and Duke following, moves along the glass facade, inspecting, then assessing the security status of the house:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I'd have to say this place                       * is a snap to break into.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I knew it.   I shouldn't have moved here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't worry. The dog'll take care                      * of anyone trying to get inside. She moves down into the living room, crossing toward one of the couches, with Harry following:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know what to do. Maybe I should move into a motel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, you don't have to do that. This is just some ding-dong that's trying to scare you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well he's succeeded. She sits down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But you don't want to give off that impression, by acting too timid or afraid, because that's what invites an aggressive attitude from certain types of men.                                                   *

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't invite this.                                  *

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For instance, don't go mincing                          * along, taking mousey little steps, and waving your hanky, because                          * you're drawing a target on yourself if you do...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do I do that?                                           *

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: )J(   MAN TROUBLE - Rev. 5/21/91

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, let's see. Just walk back and forth the way you normally do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (stands up) Well I don't normally walk back and forth, but... okay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She attempts a few steps then stops abruptly:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, I can't do it with you watching me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, but keep in mind that you want to exhibit a very confident attitude. Look like you know what you're doing and where you're going.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uhm-hmm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just remember to stop short of appearing a little dykey, because that's not attractive.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But I thought that's your point, no to attract...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, no, you always want to remain a little bit attractive. Otherwise that can set somone off too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is just impossible.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She moves back to the couch and sits down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You just can't win.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure you can, it's just a matter of degree.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well darn it, I give up...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dropping her head into her hands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: )J(   MAN TROUBLE - Rev. 5/21/91                       33

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh-oh. (moves over to her and touches her gently) Now what's this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry but this is really getting to me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He sits down next to her:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell you what. Let me take you out of here, buy you a drink, and               * see if we can't get your mind off these kind of things.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's very sweet of you, Harry. I'd like to do that.

dialogues.speaker: 36A OMITTED
dialogues.text: MAN TROUBLE - Rev. 5/20/91                            34/

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Japanese "MOOD MUSIC" over), featuring a morbid, nearly suicidal saxophone solo:) John and Harry seated at a table. She is well past the loosening effects of a second glass of wine, is not unaware that Harry is lookin at her: He lights a cigarette. As she reaches to her glass, his eyes follow the motion of her hands. She looks in front the window:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How long have you been divorced?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, I'd say seven or eight years, around there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And so you  like, well, assuming you live a  single existence, I                       * mean most  men don't seem to enjoy that, I've  read. She lifts her glass, takes a sip, then sets it back down:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have to  tell you the truth... (he  pauses)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've been  observing your hands, and I have to  use the word exquisite.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Really?   Well...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MAN TROUBLE - Rev. 4/23/91                             36

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Embarrassed by the    compliment, she reaches to her glas and nearly knocks    it over, spilling a bit of wine onto the tablecloth and    is relieved to find him gazing off and unaware of her    gaffe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're probably quite a singer too. (looking back to her) I'd like to come down and catch you sometime.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, anytime. Do you like Classical music?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Very much. Even to the degree that when it's playing on the radio, I sometimes have to turn the damn thing off. Thinking he is revealing a peculiar brand of wit, she laughs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just mean it starts to get to me too much. I can't swallow my saliva.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry.     I shouldn't have laughed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, symphonies, operettas, poems, things like that. All those type of things really get to me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looking intensely at him) Uhm hmm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A JAPANESE HOSTESS appears at the table, bowing reveren- tially and gesturing that their table is ready.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joan and Harry at a window table. A number of serving dishes and plates on the table indicate the completion of their meal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MAN TROUBLE - Rev. 4/23/91                            36A

dialogues.speaker: 37A CONTINUED
dialogues.text: She is flushed from the wine and exhilarated by her response to Harry:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're full of surprises, Harry, you know that? That you've actually read Dante's Divine Comedy I mean...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, it was a while back there that I did, yeah...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know that part? 'Yet as a wheel moves smoothly, free from jars, My will and my desire were turned by love, The love that moves the sun and other stars.'

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He nods, while Joan, hoping to disguise the extent of her emotions, looks down and begins moving her wine in circles:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For some reason, the sublimity of that always touches me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MAN TROUBLE - Rev. 4/22/91                           37.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joan and Harry come down the steps of the Inn. The sun has gone down and the lights of the city have come on. Under the following they cross the driveway to a low fence railing off an Oriental garden.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know, it's very sad. I look at my sister and all her marriages and affairs, not to mention the mess my own life is in, and I think it's very sad and very bleak that men and women can't manage to be friends.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It depends on the man and woman you're talking about. They arrive at the fence and as she speaks she rests one of her hands on the railings:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What a tragedy that sex is often such a barrier to friendship between men and women.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There I disagree with you. He places his hand over hers. She remains silent a moment, restraining her response to the gesture. Then:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know Dante and Beatrice never slept together.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is that right? (catching himself)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh yeah, I forgot that part.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, anyway... I shouldn't have had so much wine... because I prefer to go a little slow here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We can go as slow as you want... why not?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MAN TROUBLE - Rev. 4/22/91                          38.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So... (looking at him) You think men and women can be friends?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh yeah, absolutely.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joan, accompanied by Duke, moves down the driveway to a mailbox in front of the broken gates. She pauses to lavish the DOG with an exuberant display of affection and finds herself intimidated as he responds by leaping about and BARKING joyously:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alright now, don't play too rough.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The excitement has unleashed Duke's libido and as she tries to resume her mission, he makes a few attempts to rise against her flanks. Just before she approaches the mailbox, he manages to grip his paws around one of her thighs and unmistakably begins to hump her:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, no, Duke, don't do that, that's not nice. Now sitz. And behave yourself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He sits, panting, with a furtive expression on his face, watching as she steps over to the mailbox and opens it. She takes out a number of letters and sorts through them as she starts back to the house with Duke following. They are in the main addressed to Andy, but in amongst them she finds a bank statement addressed to her, as well as a letter with her name written in pencil on the envelope. She opens it, takes the contents out and stops suddenly:

dialogues.speaker: JOAN'S HAND
dialogues.text: holding a woodcut with a foxed edge revealing it was torn from the pages of a book. It is of a woman kneeling with her head on the block, while above her a hooded executioner stands with an ax in his hand. MAN TROUBLE - Rev. 5/9/91                             39.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joan and Helen, seated at a table near the concessionary building. The latter sits, tense and disturbed, an uneaten sandwich in front of her, as Helen reads from a list of suspects. (Lewie can be seen at another table, seated across from a bearded man. The other members of the Chorale, including the male soloists, are variously seated, moving about, or lounging on the campus lawn, having their lunch.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Lewie.   Mad at me.' The CAMERA PERUSES Lewie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doesn't want a divorce. Maybe he's trying to scare me, or punish me. Helen leans her head in close to Joan's:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's definitely not Lewie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're not exactly a disinterested party. You're always promoting his cause...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Number one, I've known the man for fifteen years, number two, he... loves you. She glances at Eddy, then consults the list:

dialogues.speaker: ON EDDY
dialogues.text: seated on the lawn nearby, paring an apple with a Swiss Army knife:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Eddy Revere, a little moody, but a good friend and very reliable.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An opinion I don't share, but... What do you think about Vincent?                        *

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MAN TROUBLE - Rev. 5/9/91                               4

dialogues.speaker: ON VINCENT GALLARDO
dialogues.text: gesturing expansively, as he relates some incident to his table partners:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He has a terrible temper. We know that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Vincent Gallardo.  Doubtful. We've never had an unpleasant word.' Aren't you  lucky. 'Kenneth Dowler...'                                    *

dialogues.speaker: ON KENNETH DOWLER
dialogues.text: He stands with a styrofoam cup in his hand, coming on to one of the members of the female chorus:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Always trying to connect with me, proposing private rehearsals at his apartment.' You know what he asked me yesterday?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What my cup size was.                                  * (back to the list) Steve Jewel! Who's Steve Jewel?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My piano tuner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is he weird or something?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well everyone appears weird to me right now. So I put every possible name down, except for one, who happens to be post- burglary. Helen returns to the list, tapping her finger on one of the names:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think it's him, the tree surgeon. He sounds very suspicious...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just don't tell Lewie about the phone message or the thing I got in the mail, because he'll just use it to...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I already did.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (annoyed) Helen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joan and Lewie stand in the doorway of the      rehearsal room. (A portion of the Chorus Membership       are seate chairs, and some, including Eddy Revere and      Helen, s occasional interest in the intense exchange      taking p at the door:)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm extremely concerned about this situation. I don't want you living alone up there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She regards him suspiciously. He modulates his voice to a more persuasive and intimate tone:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now come on, wouldn't you feel much safer if you moved back into our house?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I wouldn't feel comfortable about doing that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come here...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He takes hold of her arm and moves her out into the hall:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Darn it, Lewie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What? Are you afraid of your responses to me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tch...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (amorously) Why are you resisting?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: These are very upsetting, really shitty circumstances I'm dealing with and I...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you know how hard all this has been on me? Do you think it's that easy for me to admit I want you back?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Couldn't you spare yourself then?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you seeing anybody?   Just tell me that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She rolls her eyes, sighing impatiently.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, you're not the abstinent type.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please, don't judge me by your scrotal excesses, Lewie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know you're seeing somebody.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (suspicious again) Are you spying on me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on. Be open about it. (kisses her on the neck, then) Who is it?

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Her gaze meets Helen's, who, misconstruing the situation, makes an "OK" sign, delivering her semiotic sanction to the happy reunion in the hallway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (back to Lewie) Alright, I am seeing someone, okay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He pulls back, narrowing his eyes at her:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't believe you.   Who is it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Outside Joan and Harry dine. The patio is lit only by candles on the table. Socorro enters the living room with a tray holding a coffee urn and cup and closely tailed by Duke. She moves toward the patio.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Socorro sets the tray down and departs for the kitchen with Duke again falling in behind her. Joan begins to pour their coffee, glancing inside the house to see... Socorro turning lights out while the indefatigable Duke tries to mount her. Uttering some impatient complaint, she swipes at him with a napkin and the two move OUT OF VIEW THROUGH the kitchen door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know, I hate to mention this but we're having a slight problem with Duke.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What? JOAN Well... (hands him a cup) He keeps getting up and trying to ride on one's extremities.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh don't worry about that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MAN TROUBLE - Rev. 4/23/91

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Especially Socorro, who  can't speak English, let alone  German, and sometimes she has to  go pulling him from room to  room like a vacuum cleaner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, that's just normal in most of your adult males. Some percentage of the time they're gonna attempt to make these vulgar motions on your person.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He places his arm on the couch behind her:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You just have to be very firm and stay on top of him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the sky beyond the hills a helicopter beams its light.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joan and Harry   are seated on the couch having coffee as they listen to   a CHOPIN NOCTURNE. He is doing his best to emulate her   posture of thoughtful intensity as she listens, but as   he steals a look at her his adult male impulses causes   him to shift about slightly. She looks over at him:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not affecting you too much, is it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, it's very nice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's Chopin, a nocturne.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know what's affecting me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Night-piece, it means.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You are.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He reaches over and runs his hand slowly down her back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think I should say something.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't worry about it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's the problem though, I want to be honest with you...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's no problem.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He leans over and kisses her.      After a moment she bre off:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because I recently realized something about myself. That I've slept with a number of men in my life just because I didn't want them not to like me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (not averse to being one of them) Uhm hmm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But the thing is, I didn't like most of them that much, so why did I care whether they liked me or not?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know, I'm not one of these guys who's going to look upon you as an object.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, I know, that's not what I'm saying...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because I look upon a woman as a whole.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What I'm saying is I don't know if right now I might not go to bed with you because I don't want to be alone, so I thought maybe we... could try to explore other modes, or...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MAN TROUBLE - Rev. 4/22/91

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Other modes?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I mean, there are other ways of being intimate, that people don't even realize.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uhm hmm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Which doesn't mean I'm not attracted to you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But you don't want me to bring you                      * around.                                                 *

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pardon me?                                              *

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Other modes is fine. You don't have to be shy with me. (moving closer to her) I've been asked to do do every kind of thing in the book.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He kisses her once more. Her response, is far less tentative. As it begins to border on the ardent, she breaks off again:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: God, it's so hard to pioneer in this area... when you keep doing that...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joan and Harry tussle about with abandoned fervor under the covers of the bed. A fire is burning in the fireplace. Presently, the PHONE RINGS, followed by:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (on answering machine) Please leave a message after the tone... Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MAN TROUBLE - Rev. 4/22/91                             46

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: The BEEP is followed by Andy's voice, in some waning stage of sedation, coming from the phone speaker:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joan?  It's Andy... Are you there? (pause) I want to inform you that these people are drugging me...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Andy, speaking covertly into a telephone. She wears a hospital smock and is seated on the edge of bed occupied by a woman in a drug-induced state of oblivion.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's no phone in my room, or cable TV. I've had to sneak into this cell next to me, with some poor lithium zombie lying here like a comatose cabbage...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: her expression shows some concern:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe I better take this. She tries to move closer to the phone, hindered by Harry's weight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And this is the lengths this assassin is willing to go to suppress me, because he does not want me to have my book.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harry, excuse me, it's my sister. He moves off of her and she leans across his torso, pinning him to the bed as she addresses the speaker:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Andy... It's Joan. INTERCUT BETWEEN Joan and:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh you're there. Thank God.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where are you? Are you in New York?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, that's what I'm telling you. I went into the hospital first, for one day, just to have a simple bone spur...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know, you told me that, but where are you now?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... and the next thing I know I'm transported some place the hell else, against my knowledge, while I was completely medicated...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Andy, wait a minute...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you understand the implications of this, I have no underpants on, and absolutely no recourse to my rights!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joan sits up, and in her alarm is unaware that one of her hands grabs hold of a swatch of hair on Harry's chest, causing him to wince:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh God, this is because of Red, isn't it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, it's because of Red, isn't that obvious!?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Evidencing interest in their exchange, Harry manages to reach to his cigarettes on the night stand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And if he and that fuckface lawyer in his paid employ, think they can ... Wait. (whispering) I think I hear someone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joan turns to Harry, a stricken look on her face:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What am I supposed to do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Find out where she is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello? Andy? You have to tell me where you are.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MAN TROUBLE - Rev. 4/23/91                            49.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I told you, I don't know where I am, these bastards are very clever. She looks at the heavily-meshed wires covering the window

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm in some private cracker box in the boonies, with godammed wires on the windows...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ask her the name of the first                           * hospital.                                               *

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Andy, tell me the name of the                           * hospital you checked yourself into.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mount Haven, it's  in the South Bay, and don't ask  me these inane                      * questions, just do  something...                        *

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell her we'll find it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'll find it, okay, so don't worry...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hear someone coming, I have to get off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... because I'm sure there's some simple explanation... She is cut short by the abrupt sound of the PHONE HANGING UP on the other end. Again, she turns to Harry:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What should I do? Should I call the police?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. He reaches to an ashtray on the night stand and quickly douses his cigarette:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's just take a run out there.

dialogues.speaker: ON JOAN
dialogues.text: hesitant and fearful:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You mean right now?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: as Joan's car creeps along on a Saturday night Freeway, bottling up a line of cars behind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harry is none too happily confined to the passenger seat as Joan, white knuckling on the wheel, obsesses on Andy:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I told her she shouldn't do this, I mean, to be so maniacally obsessed with this soul of mud that she'd even want to write a book about him, is beyond me...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well the guy must be doing something right to have amassed that amount of wealth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But she does this, you know, she just periodically drops the entire weight of her life on me like a ton of bricks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joan, can I make a suggestion?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, please, anything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You better try an keep up a little with the flow or we're gonna get cited.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harry stands scowling for effect, his arm around Joan. MALE ADMISSION'S CLERK sits at a computer behind a counter, keying up a file, then reading if off the screen: A.C.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ellerman, Antonia. She was admitted on the third of the month and was signed out at 3:45 P.M. on the fourth, by her personal physician... JOAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How do you know he was her physician? HARRY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hell, I could come in here and say I was a doctor an' sign somebody out. JOAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And even if he was a doctor, it doesn't mean he was my sister's doctor. A.C.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: According to this he was her doctor. JOAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then who was the doctor who operated on her foot? A.C. (looking at screen)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's nothing on here about her foot. It says 'observation for clinical depression.' JOAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's a lie. She was in here for an operation, then she was drugged and taken out of here against her will. A.C.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That couldn't possibly happen, we have very strict regulations about...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MAN TROUBLE - Rev. 4/22/91                          52.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, let's stop wasting time here, where is this guy, what's his name?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looking at the screen) His name is Dr. Monroe Park. (back to them) It doesn't say where he is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't believe this, you mean there's no phone number or address?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, but I didn't type this file...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What kind of business are you running here, buddy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All I can do is give you the data I have on here. If you want to call the Physician's Registry... (gestures to a bank of pay phones) There's some public phones over there. He's probably listed with them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He turns away from them and back to the computer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joan wanders anxiously around the waiting room. In the b.g., Harry can be seen at one of the pay phones. Seeing him hang up, she stops pacing and looks toward him. POV: He approaches, answering her expectant look with a shake of the head and the disheartening news:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing.   No Dr. Monroe Park.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harry and Joan, moving toward the hospital parking lot: JOAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How am I supposed to find this man? Maybe he used a false name, or maybe he isn't even a doctor... HARRY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've got a couple of ideas here. First, we want to try an' connect with Red Layls. JOAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I don't want anything to do with Red, I'm terrified of him. HARRY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's nothing to be afraid of, believe me. JOAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I mean, you hear all kinds of things, about government kickbacks, and Panamanian drug couriers and... HARRY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know these type of guys. You take away their money and their power, and what are they. JOAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, really, I have to do something. I have to go to the police... He stops walking and takes a hold of her hand: HARRY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just hold off a bit on that, honey, will you? JOAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, that's nice. HARRY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What? JOAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You called me honey. HARRY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well that's what you are.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MAN TROUBLE - Rev. 4/23/91

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: He puts an arm around her, speaking in reassuring tones:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want to get a hold of this top private investigator, who's a close, personal friend of mine, okay, and get him to find out who this doctor is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harry, this isn't your problem and I don't want to draw you into it...                    *

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
