dialogues.text: Don't worry, we're going to find your sister. (he kisses her) Everything's going to turn out fine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: reading "Sixth Victim   of Westside Slasher." The ANGLE SHIFTS to reveal Harry   seated at a table next to a plat glass window, reading   the above paper. The view is inclusive of The House   of Bliss across the street. He lowers the paper as a waitress (VITA) appears with a Silex of coffee. She sits down opposite him, refilling his cup and addressing him in a familiar manner:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, go ahead, I've gotta hear this. Who is it this time?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, it's not what you think. This is a very unique individual I'm talking about. Plus there's a mind there, as well as a body and a face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Didn't I hear this before, about                       * the hostess at Denny's, that was a college graduate and had a mole like Elizabeth Taylor?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MAN TROUBLE - Rev. 4/23/91

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm telling you, this is something completely different. You gotta meet her. She sings opera and has                      * the hands of a hula dancer...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Under the following, June can be seen crossing the street from the House of Bliss and approaching the coffee shop:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anyway, you remember that private                      * detective that use to come in here all the time? On the portly side, bald, had kind of crossed eyes...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh.   Fred, you mean?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, that's him. How do you think I could get a hold of him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh gee, I think he's moved out of the area and went into gourmet                         * snacks.                                                *

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harry's attention is drawn to June, tapping on the window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?!                                                 *

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: June, mouthing "There's some guy over there wants to see you." Then she gestures to a Continental Town Car in the parking lot next to The House of Bliss.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harry stands back, uneasily regarding the smoked windows and the sun flaring off the glossy surfaces of the car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MAN TROUBLE - Rev. 5/9/91

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Presently, the passenger door opens and L.N. MONCRIEF, a barely discernible presence in a suit blending in with the dark interior of the car, addresses him by name:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Bliss, I'd like to have word with you, if I may.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ON JUNE, standing on the sidewalk next to The House of Bliss, looking at Harry and as he disappears into the car, she turns and goes inside the building.

dialogues.speaker: DAY
dialogues.text: The CAMERA makes a SLOW CIRCUIT around the Continental, taking in an aerial protruding from the trunk, and below it a license plate with the word "TYPHON" on it. The MOVE CONTINUES, briefly SCANNING a driver with a nasty recidivist face, seated behind the wheel, and as we come full circle, the passenger door opens and Harry gets out. He slams the door and steps back, angrily glaring at the car. The hydraulic window opens and Moncrief looks out at him:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're talking to the wrong godammed party, you know that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think it's in your best interest to hear me out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, you hear me out, friend...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He takes note of the driver (STURGE) coming around the front of the car. He stops a few feet off and unbuttons his jacket, revealing the cross-strap of a shoulder holster. Harry steps over to the window, leans down and communicates in more politic tones:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, I happen to have a very high regard for this party. And maybe I even have some feelings of a personal nature here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well I don't want to appear to be taking unfair advantage of you...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MAN TROUBLE - Rev. 5/9/91

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Goddamned right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Moncrief reaches into a briefcase, takes out a folder and makes reference to its contents as he speaks:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But in developing certain information on you, it's come to our attention that your name isn't Harry Bliss. That in fact, your name is Eugene Earl Axline...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait a minute.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And that both the I.R.S., and an impressive number of creditors in several Eastern cities... (looks up at Harry) ... seem to be somewhat interested in your whereabouts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harry stands up, leaving the vulnerable area of his stomach framed in the passenger window. When he leans back down, a deeply conflicted expression is apparent on his face:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know, that's not necessarily entirely accurate, I mean, I don't know where you come up with these so-called facts, but... (at a loss, he looks off, shaking his head) I can't go sneaking around, stealing this lady's property.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd like to pose that the name and reputation of this very decent man, is not the property of Mrs. Ellerman, or her sister.                       *

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He takes a voucher from the folder and sets the file aside:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MAN TROUBLE - Rev. 5/9/91                               5

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And it's my hope that we can avoid any unpleasant eventualities, either for you, or for someone you have such admirable feelings toward...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you mean, 'unpleasant'?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I mean that Mr. Layls is prepared to do whatever it takes to confiscate this document. And if you'd like to be of some assistance                   * to us, by finding it and turning                      * it over to me, he'd like to offer                     * you this very generous gift.                          *

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He holds the voucher out to Harry who avoids looking at it:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesus Christ, I hardly know the woman. I'm just renting a dog to her, that's all. (looking at Moncrief) What kind of a person do you take me for?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harry stands in the parking lot, watching as the Con- tinental drives off. He starts to move toward The House of Bliss, then stops and opens the voucher, braving a look at it.

dialogues.speaker: TYPHON CORPORATION CHECK
dialogues.text: signed by L.N. Moncrief and made out to the sum of $15,000.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joan's car pulls onto the street leading to Andy's house. Her gaze is drawn to a pickup parked on the street and, as she passes the vehicles she turns to look at:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MAN TROUBLE - Rev. 4/23/91                             59

dialogues.speaker: BUTCH GABLE
dialogues.text: sits in the pickup. A pile of recently-trimmed tree branches litter the ground near the truck. He turns his head to look at her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joan gets out of    the Mercedes and opens the gates. As she moves back to    the driver's door, she glances at Butch, then gets    quickly into the car. She drives in through the gates    and once again gets out to close the behind her.

dialogues.speaker: ON BUTCH
dialogues.text: He watches sullenly as her car disappears through the gates, then lifts a can of beer to his mouth and drinks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joan searches through the file cabinets and not finding what she's looking for, goes through a similar course of procedure with the desk drawers.

dialogues.speaker: UPSTAIRS
dialogues.text: On an upstairs landing, she searches through some drawers and cupboards. Then spotting Socorro on the level below:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, Socorro...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Could you come in here, por favor?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Socorro comes to the landing, Joan indicates one of the open desk drawers:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I-am-looking-for-my-sister's-book.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Socorro steps closer and glancing into the the now disorderly contents of the drawer, shakes her head defensively:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.   No es mi.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MAN TROUBLE - Rev. 4/23/91                            60.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: La manuscripto (holding an empty manila envelope in her hand) ... de mi hermana, Andy, si? (pointing at herself) I go... toda la casa... (makes a wide sweeping gesture with her hand) Everywhere... Looking y looking... (pointing at her own eye) And no es anywhere. Sabe usted?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Socorro smiles apologetically:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No se, no entiendo... (backing away) Lo siento...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Continuing to mumble some disclaimer, she moves out into the hallway and disappears.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joan rifles through the drawers of a small escritoire against the back wall of the bedroom. Then she moves toward the dressing area giving off to the bathroom, and stops as she sees the top rung of a ladder just visible above the bottom ledge of a window adjacent to the shower A small section of glass has been removed, just large enough to permit the entry of hand to the window lock.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harry behind his desk, irritable, avoiding eye contact with Joan, who is seated across from him on the window bench. (See Appendix for new items, visible on the crime collage behind Harry.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I told this detective I wanted to press charges against Red Layls, for abducting Andy, for burglarizing my apartment, for breaking into her house...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh come on, you're way off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And that he's been trying to scare and intimidate me in case I might have read something in her manuscript that he doesn't want anybody to know. And you know what he said? That I haven't given him probable cause to even go and question Red Layls, or his lawyer...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, he's right, I could've told you that. This is a man who goes fishing with the President, honey. (grabs a pack of cigarettes) He's a little high up to go around burglarizing people and sending them nasty notes. So why don't you just ease back on this thing for awhile... (lighting up) Life's too godammed short.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't do that, Harry. This is my sister. I can at least make out a missing persons report on her, and then I want to talk to the private detective friend of yours.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm trying to chase the guy down, okay? But don't go and make yourself sick...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He begins pushing the paraphernalia around on his desk:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I mean, Jesus, why don't you just get this damn thing and hand it over to me and I'll give it to these guys.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MAN TROUBLE - Rev. 4/22/91

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You mean to Red?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, to Red, or whoever...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well if I ever find, it, that's the last thing I'd do with it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dammit, you're making my work more difficult for me, you know that!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is this, have I come at the wrong time or something?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I tell you what the hell to do and you don't listen to me!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joan looks down at the floor, attempting a drollery:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, someone abates your maidenhood and suddenly feels they can start ordering you around.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not ordering you around. I'm just giving you my opinion. And maybe I get tired of hearing about this stuff all the time, this book business, this manu-whatever, and Red Layls, and your sister.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh.  Well... (deeply hurt) I'm sorry if I've overtaxed you with my problems, Harry, but I never asked you to consider them a part of your work. (stands up) So why don't we speak when you're in a better frame of mind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As she crosss to the door, Harry stands up:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah honey, now...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aw honey yourself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She disappears into the reception room and can be heard going out the door. Harry moves to the window, unhappily watching as Joan gets into the Mercedes and drives off.

dialogues.speaker: ON HARRY
dialogues.text: again seated at his desk. He stares out the window, in the throes of a moral conflict. Then making some sudden resolve he opens a drawer, takes out an envelope and a paperback book and lays them on the desk.

dialogues.speaker: PAPERBACK
dialogues.text: The price sticker is still attached above the title: Dante's Divine Comedy - Simplified Edition. He opens the book, removes the Typhon voucher from between its pages and begins addressing the envelope with the information on the check. Then he puts the voucher into the envelope and seals it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harry, envelope in hand, moves with determination down the block from his building. He approaches a mailbox, pulls the handle on the letter drop and inserts his hand inside the chute. He holds it there a moment, seized by indecision, and then brings his hand back out, still holding the envelope. Turning around, he angrily stuffs it into his back pocket and heads back to the House of Bliss.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joan, carrying two glasses of beer, crosses to exit the kitchen, the ubiquitous Duke trailing after her. She pauses to address Socorro, at the service island, vigorously hacking at the pink cadaver of chicken and tossing the dismembered pieces into a stewing pot:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, Socorro, please-keep-the-dog ... el perro, in... in piso inferior, por favor... exercise room... Tiene allergy...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MAN TROUBLE - Rev. 4/22/91                              6

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah, si.   Duke, venga aqui.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Duke returns to the kitchen and Joan moves into an enter- tainment alcove off the living room. Helen is seated on a couch, eating a slice of pizza from a delivery box on the coffee table, her attention on the TV, where a talk show is in progress:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (over above action) ... And now I'd like you to meet the director and the star of the smash hit movie, Blood And Kisses. So let's give them a nice warm welcome...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: APPLAUSE OVER. On a large TV      screen, where a fervent solicitous HOST addresses the     DIRECTOR. Seated beside him is the Actress previously     seen on the billboard a in the movie trailer of Blood     and Kisses.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Before we begin, why don't we show the audience a clip from the movie. Do you want to set it up for us?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, it's a bit... this scene involves... just go ahead and run it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: After clip:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to the Director) I must say, this is a dazzling piece of work and you two are a dynamite wedding of talents...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joan hands Helen one of the glasses, then sits down beside her. Under the following, she picks up a pen and leans over the police document now resting on the coffee table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MAN TROUBLE - Rev. 4/23/91

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But I hear you're a little   sensitive about the criticism you've   had about the amount of sexual   violence and nudity you have in the   picture...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Any scars, marks or tattoos.'                          *

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (overlapping her) Well it's absurd. In the first place, I didn't invent this genre. And it happens to be a tradition in this kind of film that women make more interesting and exciting victims than men do...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I understand...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She looks up from the document to the screen. Then both women look at each other with their mouths open:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And secondly the violence directed                      * at Mimi's character is an essential component of the story, and is not in any sense of the word, gratuitous.

dialogues.speaker: ON TV SCREEN
dialogues.text: as the Host turns to the Actress:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But, Mimi, now what about you. That scene where you run nude through Times Square with those multiple knife wounds all over your body. That must've been horrendous for you.

dialogues.speaker: ON JOAN
dialogues.text: as she throws the pen down onto the coffee table: JOAN                          ACTRESS (V.O.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Assholes.                 Yes it was, very horrendous...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Helen) Come on, let me drive you home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MAN TROUBLE - Rev. 4/22/91

dialogues.speaker: 59A CONTINUED
dialogues.text: HELEN                           ACTRESS (V.O.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait.                              But what helped me eno

dialogues.speaker: OMITTED
dialogues.text: thru

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: June, lying on a studio couch with a remote control in her hand, looking at the Actress:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... and that scene came directly after the gang rape in the elevator.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harry steps INTO VIEW, only half-listening and grumbling:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's her problem.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Also, I love Dick's taste so I knew he was handling it very artistically...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now what's she complaining about?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He holds out his hand to June, requesting the remote control:

dialogues.speaker: HARRY HOST, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Give me that.                      Well, you're just Iwo's got some shit she's          Don't go away, we'll b looking at...                      right back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MAN TROUBLE - Rev. 4/22/91                              6

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... I come over here to look at the ball game and you give me these clowns.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A COMMERCIAL comes on. June hands him the remote and he sits down on the couch, channeling to a BASEBALL GAME:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I mean, what's wrong with these women.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You want a know something?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They don't want to hear the truth, that's what disturbs me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MAN TROUBLE - Rev. 4/23/91                             67

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's some people that don't treat me like you do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You tell them the truth and they come at you with a cleaver.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know one guy that says very complimentary things to me, like that I have nice features and a sense of humor.                                       *

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What guy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Some guy I met, that likes me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He looks at her, then reaches over and places a hand affectionately on the nape of her neck:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're going to leave me, lard, just after I've broken you in, and taught you the fine art of dog training?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe. (waits for a                                   * response, then)                               * As if you cared.                                      *

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shakes his head and sighs) Women. (then back to the TV) What's the score?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joan and Helen enter the garage. Joan gets into the driver's seat and closes the door, while Helen maneuvers on her crutches around to the passenger side.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joan turns the IGNITION ON and as she starts to buckle herself in, her eye catches the movement of something at the back of the garage.

dialogues.speaker: X64 CONTINUED
dialogues.text: From behind a sheet of    plywood resting against the bac wall of the garage, and    just visible in the darkness, man's hand can be seen    reaching to the handle of an ax amongst other gardening    tools in an iron rack. Helen opens the passenger door and Joan whispers to her:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Helen, quick, get in the car!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Helen leans down and looks in at her:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Looking in the   direction   of Joan's gaze she sees the figure of a man   wearing a   hood over his head, steppin out from behind   the sheet   of plywood, holding the ax his hand and as   he moves   toward the front of the car, screams. He lifts the ax over his head and swings it down vio- lently, cleaving the blade into the hood of the Mercedes. (From inside the house, DUKE can be heard BARKING furiously.) Joan leaps from the car and in stark terror, runs out of the garage toward the house. Stopped by the sounds of HELEN'S HYSTERIA, she turns around to see her, hampered by her crutches and unable to move. ON the hooded man's eyes, shifting their homicidal intent from Helen to Joan. Joan runs back into the garage and frantically tries to pull Helen away from her death grip on the door handle. The man begins stalking around the front of the car toward her. She grabs one of Helen's crutches and raises it up as if to hit him. As he steps back to the ax and tries to extract it from the hood, she suddenly rushes at him and begins belaboring him with the crutch. He lifts an arm to fend off the blows while his other hand con- tinues to tug at the ax handle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Helen!   Help me!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't!   I can't move!!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Raising both arms to protect himself, the man is forced to give ground, moving further back into the garage, with Joan continuing to batter at him. Then in a sudden burst of rage he grabs hold of the crutch, yanks it from her grasp and lunges at her. )O(    MAN TROUBLE - Rev. 5/30/91

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUOUS ACTION
dialogues.text: Socorro exits her bedroom to the hall and heads down the the stairs to investigate the cause of DUKE'S BARKING.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Socorro steps into the room. The door automatically closes behind her. Duke, in a frenzy, leaps at her, then runs toward the glass doors. He hurls himself at the glass, then returns to Socorro. Thinking he's gone rabid, she screams and tries to hide behind one of the weight racks. The above course of procedure continues, with Duke trying desperately to indicate his intentions, chasing Socorro around and over the press benches and exercise paraphernalia.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Helen SCREAMING OVER:) The hooded man has Joan up against the garage wall. One of his hands is on her throat and the other is held over her mouth. In the struggle, she manages to sink her teeth into his hand. He pulls it free and hits her across the face. She reaches to a flower pot on a potting shelf and pole-axes him on the top of the head. It staggers him briefly and enables her to move out of his grasp. She immediately grabs an iron rake from the garden rack and turns fiercely toward him. Now standing, vanquished, breathing hard, and apparently having had enough, he begins to back away from her. When he reaches a safe distance, he turns and moves quickly off, disappearing into the dark.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joan, her garments soiled and disheveled from the pre- vious scene, comes from the vicinity of the front door, closely followed by Duke and Harry:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why didn't you have the damn dog with you, that's what he's for!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I told you, he was in the house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What the hell good is that! You have to have him with you at all times!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: )P(    MAN TROUBLE - Rev. 6/4/91

dialogues.speaker: X64D CONTINUED
dialogues.text: As they move into the living room, Helen, wearing Joan's chenille robe, her hair wildly askew, can be seen in the kitchen area, holding a bottle of liquor in one hand and searching through a cupboard for a glass.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN HARRY
dialogues.text: I can't have him with me         Didn't I tell you, right all the time, he's killing       from the start, it's my mucous membranes...           very dangerous to fool

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No you didn't, I said he was dangerous, and you said he wasn't...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, but that's before he tried to part your hair with an axe!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know if it was him.   Maybe it was this tree surgeon...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She starts to move toward the bedroom and he stops her:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait a minute. How tall was he? About six one? Kind of ugly?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Helen, now with a drink in her hand, steps INTO VIEW behind Harry:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He was about your height.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, he wasn't, he was much taller.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well let's not quibble, for god sakes. The  man is a complete maniac... (to Harry) And excuse me for saying, but this isn't a job for an amateur...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But wait, he couldn't be the same man who burglarized my apartment, because that's before I came up here...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: )P(    MAN TROUBLE - Rev. 6/4/91

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Forget about him. I know what I'm talking about...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joan, if you don't call the                            * police, I'm not staying here.                          *

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She takes the drink out of Helen's hand and drains it while Harry continues:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Guy like Red Layls have hit men working for them, that drive them around and do their dirty work for them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gee whiz, first it isn't Red, now it is Red. I can't keep up with these sudden reversals.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alright... I'm calling a cab.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ON Helen, as she clumps away in the direction of the guest bedroom:

dialogues.speaker: OMITTED
dialogues.text: thru 67

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harry sits on chaise trying not to catch glimpses of Joan, who is changing her clothes in the closet. The mood is more subdued.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know what I think?   It's more than one person.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not more than one person. I'm telling you who the hell it is!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But I don't think Red would have someone sing into my answering machine...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: )P(   MAN TROUBLE - Rev. 6/4/91

dialogues.speaker: CLOSET
dialogues.text: Joan sticks her head out door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It doesn't seem like something he'd do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dammit, Joan!! She steps out of the closet and comes toward the bedroom, dressed in one of Andy's negligees.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: God, what is this?! I can't say anything to you anymore, you're so darn touchy!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can mention anything you want,                     * honey. I'm just trying to keep you from turning up face down, that's all. After a moment:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I mean, I can't leave you up here alone now... She moves toward the bed, aware of Harry staring at her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's Andy's --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's very becoming on you. She sits down on the edge of the bed, looking over at him

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- Maybe I don't quite fill it out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes you do. After a brief moment:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well? He remains seated, looking at her. She reaches to the answering machine on the night stand, disconnects it, then once again looks over at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: )P(   MAN TROUBLE - Rev. 6/4/91

dialogues.speaker: 68A CONTINUED
dialogues.text: He gets up and comes over to the bed and reaches a hand down to touch the side of her face. She looks up at him: She takes his hand, he sits down on the bed beside her and they begin to make love.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harry stands watching Joan. She pulls the Mercedes half- way out of the garage and stops the car to call out to hi

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you going to do now?   Are you going to leave?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, I'm going to skip down the hill, take care of a few things, pick up some clothes...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Could you be back for dinner, around 7:00?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.   Sure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She waves to him     and pulls the rest of the way out of garage, revealing     the ax handle still embedded in the front of the car,     its handle sharply angled up from t hood like a soup     ladle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MAN TROUBLE - Rev. 4/23/91                             74

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: (NOTE: Harry steps toward the car. H: "Let me pull that thing out of the hood for you." J: "Later, I don't have time right now.") She blows him a kiss. Then moves down the driveway toward the gates. He stands watching until her car disappears. Then he moves to front door of the house and finds it locked.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Moving around to    the side of the house, he unbuckles h wrist watch and    puts it in his pants pocket. Then he steps up to the    service porch door, sees Socorro insid putting clothes    into a washer and raps on the glass panel. She smiles in recognition and opens the door for him:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ella no esta aqui.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just want to look for my... (indicating his wrist) ... watch, I think I left it... (gesturing toward the living room) ... in there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah si, es okay. She steps out of the way to let him in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks, Soco.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harry searches through the file cabinet then moves over to the desk and as Joan had done previously, goes through the drawers. Duke sits in the doorway, watching him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He opens and inspects the contents of the same drawers and cupboards Joan had searched.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Duke follows Harry's every movement, as he engages in a deft, professional search of the bedroom. He goes through the bureau drawers, the closet shelves, a pair of suitcases, then crosses to one of the two nightstands. Finding nothing in the drawer, he moves around to its mate on the other side of the bed.

dialogues.speaker: HARRY
dialogues.text: He opens the drawer, glances inside and starts to close it when he sees:

dialogues.speaker: DRAWER
dialogues.text: A gift envelope with his name on it rests on a small wrapped box. He picks it up, opens the envelope and takes out a plain white card with a handwritten message on it:

dialogues.speaker: CARD
dialogues.text: "Thank you for everything you've done for me, Harry, and mostly, for being in my life. I love you, Joan."

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO SCENE
dialogues.text: Harry sits down on the bed, feeling the utter deficiency of heart implicit in this act of treachery and deception. He stares blankly into space for a moment. Then he puts the card back, picks up the box and without removing it from the drawer, gives it a little shake.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Adele stands playing a garden hose over the lawn. Two pop-eyed little DOGS YAP and mill about her legs. In the b.g., Harry's van can be seen in the driveway, and presently he appears from the side of the house, carrying a suitcase and a few items of clothes. As he moves to the van and opens the door, her attention is drawn to him:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harry! What the hell do you think you're doing?

dialogues.speaker: 72A CONTINUED
dialogues.text: He sets the suitcase down, lays the clothes over it and crosses the lawn to her:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just got a phone call, honey, from a prominent entertainer up in Vegas, a very well-known singer...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who is it, Paul Anka?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's a rock star, you probably wouldn't know the name. Anyway, I gotta run a couple a dogs up to him...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know, it's T-minus zero and counting, Harry, on this whole shitty deal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now Iwo, don't blow this way out of proportion. You  think I want to do this. I need  the extra cash right now, believe me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you leave, I'm getting Top Lock to come over and change the front and back doors!

dialogues.speaker: HARRY ADELE
dialogues.text: Look, I'm only talking                (screaming at about a short period of                the dogs) time here.                         Ming! Tippy! Shut

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I mean it! You get in that van, and I'm taking my building back and putting in a Fingernail Salon!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on now, honey, don't say things like that...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He puts an arm around her, giving her a perfunctory hug:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MAN TROUBLE - Rev. 4/22/91                             77

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's not make a big issue out of it... (kisses her on the cheek) Okay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Without waiting for a response, he moves back across the lawn toward the van and is stopped mid stride as a strong spray from the hose hits him squarely on the back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They are finishing dessert and coffee by candlelight. Joan's hands encircle Harry's wrist with a new watch.

dialogues.speaker: ON HARRY AND JOAN
dialogues.text: Seated at the dining table. He is deeply morose and makes a half-hearted attempt to enthuse as she tries to secure the clasp. (The empty box and the card rest on the table next to the watch he used to deceive his way into the house.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's really very nice looking, honey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you like it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.   I do.   Very much.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She finishes securing the watch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're welcome.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah it's great and it's something I really needed, so...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He leans over and kisses her on the cheek, then picks up his fork and begins poking with disinterest at his food. Joan's eyes remain on him, trying to divine his mood:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is anything wrong?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. Nothing's wrong.   Everything's fine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She resumes eating. Then, desirous of     drawing his att tion, she fixes her gaze on the table    top and smiles pensively, making the assumption that    he is looking at her. When no response is forthcoming,     she attempts a verbal solicitation:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (without looking up) You're probably wondering why I'm smiling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He looks over at her:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was just thinking that I find this moody side of you very attractive.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, uh-huh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In fact, if you want to know, and I can see you're dying to... (reaches over and caresses his back) I completely adore you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, same here, honey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why are you all wet?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He lays his fork down and tries to make an awkward and difficult excursion into the truth:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know, there is something I feel I gotta say here, Joan, that's been preying on my mind. Something I maybe should've handled a bit differently with you from the start, about this particular situation I'm in...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What situation?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MAN TROUBLE - Rev. 5/1/91                               7

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, you recall I mentioned to you a while back, that I was finished...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Socorro steps INTO VIEW, addressing Joan with great excitement:

dialogues.speaker: SOCORRO HARRY
dialogues.text: Senora, ven rapido. Mira           ... with a certain que estoy en las noticias          relationship, and I, de la televicion!                  more or less, am, She motions Joan to follow and disappears into the kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joan and Harry, looking toward the television set. Socorro stands next to the screen, pointing at herself, a small figure near the front door of Andy's house. In the f.g. a television REPORTER addresses the camera:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mira, alli estoy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (over the above) ... Regarding an earlier press                        * release announcing Mrs. Ellerman's                    * intention to publish her book,                        * which purportedly contains                            * several explosive details concerning                  * Redmon Layls' controversial business dealings.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harry coughs loudly as Moncrief appears, standing outside a government office building, encircled by a picket of microphones attached to a number of floating hands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Layls' lawyer, Laurence                           * Moncrief, had this to say when asked if he was concerned about what might be revealed in the Ellerman book:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MAN TROUBLE - Rev. 5/1/91

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have no knowledge whatsoever of Mrs. Ellerman's so-called book, or her alleged disappearance, which appears to have all the ear marks of a publicity stunt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Harry, outraged) Can you believe this?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She turns contemptuously back to   the screen. The Reporter now stands in the f.g.   of a three-story build- ing. SLIGHTLY OUT OF FOCUS, but    discernible over its entrance, are the words: Monroe    Park Center.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Recent reports of Layls' failing health were denied by his personal physician, Dr. Park. When questioned in a phone interview, he responded that the elusive billionaire...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the Reporter continues, Joan moves closer to the TV.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... was recovering from quote, 'nothing more than the treatment of an ordinary virus.' Meanwhile...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She points to the sign over the building's entrance:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you see that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?                            ... this seems to be another intriguing

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JOAN                     episode in the stormy Monroe Park! That's the          career of Andy Ellerman, name of the man who checked      one-time Washington Andy out of the hospital!        playgirl and erstwhile companion to one of the

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HARRY                    country's wealthiest I'm not sure that was the        men... This is Heidi guy's name.                      Robles reporting to you from Monroe Park Center in San Dimas...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MAN TROUBLE - Rev. 5/1/91                              81

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JOAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes it was.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She looks quickly back to the screen -- a commercial comes on. JOAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What did she say? San Dimas? (then to Harry)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where's San Dimas? Without waiting for his answer, she strides across the room: JOAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's call the T.V. station and find out. HARRY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is not the way you want to go about this, honey. As she moves OUT OF VIEW into the living room, he turns to Socorro:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HARRY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell her, Soco. She shouldn't mess with these people.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joan comes out of the bedroom with her purse and jacket and with Harry following, crosses the living room: HARRY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will you just once take the benefit of my advice?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MAN TROUBLE - Rev. 4/22/91                              8

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: First you tell me I go around acting too timid...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, but this is a whole different situation here...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And now when I suddenly feel like I could save the Pope in an earthquake, you start trying to...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is not the Pope we're talking about here, believe me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's just a figure of speech.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They disappear out the front door. 76   EXT. ANDY'S HOUSE/DRIVEWAY & GARAGE - NIGHT Joan comes out the front door, Harry moving along beside her, as she moves crossing briskly toward the garage:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dammit, Joan, these people are holding all the cards. They'll probably throw you into that bughouse with your sister.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She begins moving a little less purposively than before:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You want to go there and call 'em a bunch of names, throw a lot of accusations at them? They don't care. People with that kind of money behind them, with their kind of connections, they never go to jail, you never see them behind bars.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They stop in front of the garage where Joan's car is parked:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Am I getting through to you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MAN TROUBLE - Rev. 4/22/91

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alright.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Though evidently very troubled, she nevertheless goes into the garage, opens the driver's door and gets into the car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to himself) Jesus Christ.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Mercedes moves along one of the surface streets with the ax handle still protruding from its hood. FOLLOWING ON the car as it enters a ramp and pauses before merging into the dense traffic on the eastbound Hollywood Freeway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joan, staring grimly out the windshield as she snails along in the right-hand lane. Harry begins shifting fitfully around, grumbling:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is just nuts, what you're doing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will you stop trying to undermine me every inch of the way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (gesturing out the window) Look at this goddamned traffic.                         *

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anyway, I didn't ask you to drag along with me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're the one that's dragging along. (gesturing at a semi in front of them) Go around the goddamned truck.                          *

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MAN TROUBLE - Rev. 4/22/91                          84.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't tell me what to do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, just let me drive the goddamned car, that's all I ask.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why should I let you drive?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why? I'll tell you why, because you're a terrible driver, that's why.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, now all the ugly little truths are coming out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You operate this vehicle like it was a cane with a red tip painted on the end of it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't talk to me, Harry. I mean it, just don't say another word to me!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He angrily folds his arms across his chest, assuming a sullen silence for a moment. The traffic has come to a grid-lock stop, raising their anxiety levels:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was doing just fine until you started in on me...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (gesturing at the ax) Driving around with a goddamned ax stuck in your car...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And now look at me.   I've got purpose tremors...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He suddenly opens the door, gets out and moves to the ax handle. Joan watches as he makes several unsuccessful attempts to pull the ax out of the hood of the car. MAN TROUBLE - Rev. 4/22/91                            85.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He gives up and moves back to the passenger door, passing a man in an adjacent car, looking curiously from the ax handle to him:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is something the fuck bothering you, pal? He gets into the Mercedes and slams the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joan moves quickly through the parking lot and onto a walkway leading to the hospital entrance. Harry, trailing behind, calls up to her:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can I at least offer some advice?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good. Just barge into  the place, honey, and play the big hero. (pauses for a response)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When he tells you your sister's not there, what're you going to do, cry? She stops walking and as he moves up beside her, looks defiantly at him:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay.   What?

dialogues.speaker: HARRY AND JOAN
dialogues.text: He takes her by the hand and leads the way over the grounds toward the rear quarters of the hospital.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ON Harry and Joan, as he tries several locked doors before finding one that gives entrance into the hospital. MAN TROUBLE - Rev. 4/23/91                             86

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They step inside a narrow hallway leading to one of the main corridors of the hospital. As they edge past a laundry cart outside a utility room, Harry releases her hand. She moves ahead, then experiencing a sudden loss of nerve, stops and looks back to see Harry rummaging through the dirty laundry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harry, in a white doctor's jacket, with Joan at his side, move through a corridor. As she glances nervously about, then at him:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This isn't going to work.   You look like a busboy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They approach a nurses' station and Harry steps forward to address one of TWO NURSES behind the counter:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excuse me, Nurse...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ON Harry, Joan and Nurse One. Presently the Nurse ges- tures to a stairwell leading to the second floor. Joan and Harry move in the direction indicated.

dialogues.speaker: ON HARRY AND JOAN
dialogues.text: Moving into the stairwell.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PICKING UP Harry and Joan moving down the above hallway, looking at the room numbers:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hope you know what you're doing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't worry.   Just do what I told you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They approach room 206. (In the hallway outside the adjacent room, an old man in a hospital gown is seated in a wheelchair. He wears a stingy-brim hat on his head and reads a pamphlet entitled "Colostomy and You.")

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MAN TROUBLE - Rev. 4/23/91                          87.

dialogues.speaker: 84A CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Harry reaches to the door, opens it, ushers Joan inside and is about to follow, when:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doctor!   Just a minute please!

dialogues.speaker: NURSE
dialogues.text: Approaching up the hallway.

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO SCENE
dialogues.text: He takes a few steps towards her, assuming his all-purpos scowl:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's the problem, dear?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're trying to contact Doctor                     * Park, just to be sure he's authorized you to examine Mrs. Ellerman, because you know, we have to follow certain...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I understand.    You're doing your job.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (trying to look around him) Where did your assistant...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She had to step inside for a moment, to relieve herself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joan is now wearing Andy's hospital gown, while Andy is hastily buttoning herself into Joan's blouse: ANDY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And if this little kinglet of corporate shit thinks he can get away with this, he's greatly mistaken. Just wait 'til he hears what I'm going to come out with now. Joan thrusts her skirt at Andy:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Put this on. ANDY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Remember when he passed me off as staff and I was put on official government payroll all through Maui and the Yucatan Mission?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I don't.   And hurry up, will you. And as Andy steps into the skirt, Joan takes over the uncompleted buttoning chores: ANDY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes you do, remember, when I almost died of the vomito negro? Well that's when he was doing all that illegal oil drilling off the Mexican Gulf... She turns to look critically at her face in the mirror: ANDY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have you got any lipstick?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ON Harry and the Nurse, as before: NURSE ONE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I assume you're a fairly recent associate of the doctor's? HARRY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's very correct.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uhm hmmm...   What do you specialize in?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd say female troubles, mainly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, so Dr. Park feels there's a gynecological involvement here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sometimes he does, yes. (a beat) By the way, did anyone ever tell you what attractive eyebrows you have?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (thrown) Oh, well, no, they haven't...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Her attention is diverted to a SECOND NURSE entering the wing, calling out to her and making a summoning gesture:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excuse me a minute, Doctor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harry watches as she moves away, and while the two Nurses engage in an exchange some distance down the hall, he steps back to the door, opens it and sticks his head inside:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: of Joan and Andy, the former whispering urgently in ref- erence to the latter's red hair:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about her hair?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who's he?

dialogues.speaker: ON OLD MAN
dialogues.text: now snoozing in the wheelchair. Harry's hand MOVES INTO FRAME and deftly removes his hat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MAN TROUBLE - Rev. 4/22/91                          90.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: of the Second Nurse on her way back to the main corridor, while Nurse One is returning to Harry. As she comes up to him:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That was my superior. She tells me Dr. Park is in surgery and she suggests that you wait in the Administrative Lounge until we can get a hold of him. Would that be alright?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Certainly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He moves to the door, opens it, blocking the Nurse's view into it with his body.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN
dialogues.text: Looking frightened at her imminent abandonment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't worry Mrs. Ellerman, we'll be right back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Andy, wearing dark glasses and with her hair hidden up under the stingy-brim hat, steps out into the hallway.

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO SCENE
dialogues.text: Harry takes her by the arm and looks amiably toward the Nurse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Which way?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (gesturing a direction) That way, Doctor, and thank you very much for your patience.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't mention it. The Nurse watches briefly as they move away, then extracting a key from her pocket, she steps over to the door and locks it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harry, outside the Mercedes, glancing around furtively, while inside the car, Andy continues to perseverate about Red Layls as she struggles out of Joan's clothes: ANDY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And this man, who wouldn't know the truth if it came up and spit him in the eye, is accusing me of lying... She hands him the skirt out through the window: ANDY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know what that prick had his lawyer say to me? Harry lays the skirt on the hood of the car and begins getting out of the doctor's jacket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That I   was a pretty, grudge- bearing   little malcontent, grasping at some   splinter of celebrity for myself   at his expense. Can you believe   that? She hands him out the blouse and he turns politely away from her semi-nudity as he hands her the doctor's jacket. HARRY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here, put this on. ANDY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I mean, the arrogance... (getting into the jacket)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What did she say your name was?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harry. ANDY (flirtatiously)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have you got a cigarette, Harry? He takes a pack of cigarettes and a lighter from his shirt pocket and hands them to her: HARRY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stay in the car. Don't talk to anybody, and I'll be right back. He immediately moves off, rolling Joan's clothes into a bundle and heading back to the hospital grounds. MAN TROUBLE - Rev. 4/22/91                             92

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harry, hurrying across the grounds to the rear of  the hospital. (In the distant b.g. beyond him, the Continental can be seen pulling up and parking on  a street bordering the hospital. Moncrief, carrying   a briefcase, and his chauffeur (Sturge), get out and   move onto a walkway leading to the hospital entrance)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harry rounds the corner of the hospital building and stops: Two male hospital employees are smoking and conversing outside the door he had previously entered with Joan.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fuck! He turns and moves OUT OF SIGHT.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joan, in a state of extreme nervousness, paces about the room. Her perambulations bring her near the door to the hallway. She reaches to the doorknob, tests it and finds she is locked in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Christ. A soft WHISTLE comes from the vicinity of the windows behind her, followed by Harry's voice, whispering:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joan?   Are you there? She crosses quickly to the windows, looking out through t thick wire mesh at Harry:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He stands several feet below, looking up at the window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is that you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, it's me.    Hurry up, will you!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm having a little trouble getting back in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh great, Harry. What have you got me into?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't worry, honey...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have to get me out of here!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everything's under control, just hang on a few more minutes and I'll be right back, okay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As he moves out of sight, her attention is drawn to the sound of MUFFLED VOICES in the hallway. In a panic, she starts toward the bathroom, changes her mind, moves to the bed and gets into it. As the door begins to open, she grabs one of the pillows and quickly covers her head with it.

dialogues.speaker: ON MONCRIEF AND STURGE
dialogues.text: Being let into the room by a male nurse. He closes the door after them and the two men look toward the bed:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Andy?   It's Larry Moncrief.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: of the unresponsive figure under the covers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Would you care to sit up for a minute? I'd like to talk to you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ON Andy in the driver's seat of the Mercedes. The window is rolled up and she puffs impatiently on a cigarette. Presently, she catches sight of something out the driver's window and turns to look:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MAN TROUBLE - Rev. 4/22/91                            94.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: A sleek black car with opaque'd windows pulls into a parking slot several yards away. A faded male beauty, somewhere in his 50s, gets out of the rear passenger door and as he moves to the walkway leading to the hospital grounds: She quickly rolls down the window and angrily addresses him:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You son of a bitch!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: RED LAYLS looks toward the Mercedes and as he approaches, we can see a medical beeper attached to his belt.

dialogues.speaker: ANDY
dialogues.text: Her hair still hidden under the stingy-brim, her eyes unrecognizable behind the dark glasses.

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO SCENE
dialogues.text: He comes up to the car, peering closely at its occupant:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who is it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who the hell do you think it is?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sweetheart?   Is that you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She pulls the dark glasses off...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No thanks to you, it's me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... and throws them onto the dashboard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harry hastens back along the walkway to the parking lot. Once again he halts abruptly in his tracks:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aw, Jesus.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MAN TROUBLE - Rev. 4/22/91

dialogues.speaker: RED LAYLS
dialogues.text: Opening the driver's door and reaching in to take hold of Andy's arm. (As she steps out of the car, we see that below the doctor's jacket Harry had intended to retrieve, she is bare-legged and wears Joan's high heels.)

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO SCENE
dialogues.text: Harry turns and strides back toward the hospital.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Moncrief places a briefcase on a nightstand next to the bed. As he opens it and searches through its contents:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Before he arrives, I'd like you to take a look at a list of certain deletions and expurgations, which if agreed to...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He removes several typed pages, stapled together and looks down at the pillow covering Joan's face:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... Red is, very generously, I think, prepared to offer his sanction to a sanitized version of your book.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No response. Moncrief glances over at Sturge, standing near the door, then back at the figure on the bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think you should know, that if you push this too far, you run the risk of having him withdraw his consent to your well-being. (pauses, then) I don't think we want that, do we, Andy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He reaches down and removes the pillow.    Joan looks fea fully up at him:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Andy's not here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can see that, Miss Spruance. Would you care to tell me where she is?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MAN TROUBLE - Rev. 4/22/91

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: She sits up, glancing uneasily at Sturge, then attempts to assert herself boldly to Moncrief:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As a matter of fact, she happens to be on her way to the police right now, accompanied by a close friend of mine...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Her bluff is immediately belied by:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Honey?    It's me again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Moncrief and Joan look toward the window:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have to tell you something.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joan jumps from the bed and moves to address Harry:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't say a word, Harry!       I'm not alone!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Moncrief looks at the chauffeur, gesturing toward the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sturge.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sturge exits to the hallway, leaving the door open.

dialogues.speaker: HARRY
dialogues.text: standing below the window, whispering:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who's there?

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO SCENE
dialogues.text: Moncrief steps in beside Joan:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think you better come in here, Mr. Bliss.

dialogues.speaker: ON GROUNDS
dialogues.text: Muttering under his breath:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MAN TROUBLE - Rev. 4/22/91

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the distant b.g., the previously seen old man is being wheeled along the main walkway by a hospital orderly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just go get Andy and leave, will you!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's what I'm trying to tell you...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm a little disappointed to find you defaulting on our agreement.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joan looks from Moncrief to Harry:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What agreement?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Moncrief) Bullshit! I never agreed to anything! (to Joan) This asshole approached me and tried to bribe me into working for them, and I told him to go to hell!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I believe an agreement was implicit in your acceptance of my check.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, you want to see your check?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He begins searching frantically through his pockets:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MAN TROUBLE - Rev. 4/22/91

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh Harry, how could you...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Honey, don't go by anything this guy says, because I'm the only one who knows what the hell I'm doing. (pulls the envelope from his back pocket) It just slipped my mind, I was going to tell you. (holds it up) See? I never cashed the fucking thing!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He tears the envelope in half and as he throws it on the ground, a hand the size of a large dictionary reaches INTO FRAME and grabs him roughly by the back of his shirt collar.

dialogues.speaker: HARRY AND STURGE
dialogues.text: lurching about in a grappler's waltz below the window. In the b.g. the old man can be seen leaning down to the walkway, picking up the stingy-brim hat and returning it to his head. She turns from the window to see a subdued Andy entering, her eyes showing signs of recent weeping. Behind her in the hall, Moncrief can be seen greeting Red Layls. Joan moves over to her...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you alright?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... And in response to Andy's stoical nod:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No you're not. (embracing her) What did that bastard do to you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I need a Kleenex.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She moves toward the nightstand with Joan following:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MAN TROUBLE - Rev. 4/22/91

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know what they're trying to do, don't you? To force you into signing some kind of agreement that...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait, I want to tell you what he said to me...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She extracts a tissue from a dispenser on the nightstand:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He said I was the only woman he's ever really cared for...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And when he said it... (blowing her nose) ... he had a tear in his eye...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joan's jaw goes slack in disbelief.

dialogues.speaker: ON RED
dialogues.text: Glancing sourly at the two women, as he and Moncrief enter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well this moves to the top of the list, Red, as one of your more stunning achievements.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (irritably) Get me something cold to drink, will you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Certainly.

dialogues.speaker: ON SISTERS
dialogues.text: Speaking in hushed, and in Joan's case, urgent tones, while, in the b.g., Moncrief exits to the hallway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Andy, you don't know what you're saying. You're suffering from hostage syndrome or something.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, after all I do love him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You 'love' him?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, he's been a very important man in my life, you know that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (raising her voice) Oh, now he's not a fecal-faced, great white shark!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Andy looks over at RED, now seated in one of the two chairs in the room. Moncrief can be seen re-entering and joining him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know where she got that. (back to Joan) Will you please keep your voice down. He's very sensitive to what people say.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Sensitive'? Have you lost all your beads?! This man had you kidnapped and kept in a drugged stupor for the last three weeks, and now he's...

dialogues.speaker: ON HARRY
dialogues.text: Stepping into the doorway, holding Struge in a painful armlock:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alright, what the hell's going on in here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who's this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's the dog trainer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought he was working for us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MAN TROUBLE - Rev. 4/22/91                             10

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well there seems to be a little grey area there, Red.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Harry) Come over here, I want to talk to you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harry releases Sturge and moves over to Layls, offering his hand and trying to maintain his gruff manner:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Layls...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joan looks with dismay at Harry's apostasy as he shakes "the great man's" hand, then quickly returns her atten- tion to Andy:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will you listen to me! This man is not only a bastard, he's a scummy, soul-less little thug and a criminal!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you implying that I have defective judgement in men, Joanie?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Red and Harry, as before. In the b.g., a hospital employee wheels a cart holding several glasses of iced tea. Moncrief moves over to the cart and the employee exits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just  want a say, that though you're  someone in a category I admire,  you've gone to some lengths  on this thing here, that I don't  entirely agree with...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sit down. I have a neck condition and it aggravates me to have to look up at you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay.   No problem.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As he seats himself in the other chair, Red reaches up and takes a glass of tea offered by Moncrief:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But I want to go on and finish my thought on this, because...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MAN TROUBLE - Rev. 4/22/91

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know, I'm not in the best of health right now, and I've been advised to avoid excitement...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harry takes a second glass from Moncrief:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So if you intend to do that... (after a sip of tea) I might just have to have my shock troops blow your brains out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, uh huh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (holds the glass up to Moncrief) More sugar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And furthermore, this 'sensitive' man's lawyer more than implied they were willing to put your feet, as well as probably mine, into a block of cement!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh that's just all talk... (calling over to Moncrief) Would somebody please get me my clothes!

dialogues.speaker: ON HARRY AND RED
dialogues.text: (In the b.g., Sturge exits on another flunky errand.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just put yourself, Harry, for a moment, in the shoes of a man whose sole intention is to leave the world a better place than he found it, only to discover those intentions have been painfully slandered by someone he'd given both his heart and his economic support to, not to mention his trust...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MAN TROUBLE - Rev. 4/23/91                              1

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (nodding his head) Uhm-hmm.

dialogues.speaker: ON JOAN
dialogues.text: looking over at Harry, protesting loudly:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harry, I can't believe you're sitting there nodding your head and having a tea party with these crooks!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not nodding my head, honey, I'm just listening to the man.

dialogues.speaker: ON ANDY
dialogues.text: as Harry, in the b.g., resumes his exchange with Red:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who is this guy, anyway? Isn't he a little sleazy, Joanie, a bit infra dig? I mean Lewie's a bit of a stiff, but...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're going to talk to me about sleaze, when you consorted with some maniac tree surgeon, who was flicking his tongue out at me like some rutting iguana, and groping at his naturalia at three in the morning?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, 'him.'

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She looks to the chauffeur, re-entering with her clothes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh 'him'?!   He came at me with an ax!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, he's very immature.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Before Joan can respond, she crosses to take her belongings from Sturge, and as she moves toward the bathroom:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MAN TROUBLE - Rev. 4/22/91

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: of the beleaguered maiden she hoped to rescue, pausing on her way, to lean down and kiss the cheek of the dragon she meant to slay.

dialogues.speaker: ON JOAN
dialogues.text: As Moncrief steps up to her, offering a glass of tea:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miss Spruance, would you care for a...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She moves past him, striding over to Harry and Red:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excuse me!

dialogues.speaker: ON RED
dialogues.text: Raising a baleful eye to Joan:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know what    kind of spell you've cast on my    sister, but it doesn't extend to    me...

dialogues.speaker: ON JOAN
dialogues.text: Standing above Layls:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In fact, I've been to the police and I intend to press charges against you...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Honey, he's not supposed to get excited.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (overlapping him) ... Not only for having my apartment burglarized but for breaking into Andy's house, as well as hiring someone to frighten, harass and intimidate me!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MAN TROUBLE - Rev. 4/22/91                             10

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know, maybe you better not...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, Dammit!

dialogues.speaker: HARRY JOAN
dialogues.text: He's got a bad neck...            I'm not afraid of these snakes!!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She looks defiantly from Harry to Moncrief, then back to Red, who regards her coldly for a moment, then:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I never much cared for you, young lady. And I find your display of anger both unattractive and unfeminine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Red) Now wait a minute...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (overlapping) I'm not here to beg your good opinion...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Under the following, Red's BEEPER begins SIGNALING:

dialogues.speaker: HARRY JOAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: ... Red Layls or not, you         ... or to find out don't insult this party in        the right amount of my presence.                      attractiveness and likability I'm supposed to render up!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Without removing his eyes from Joan's, he raises the beeper to his mouth and presses the speaker button:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doctor Park is trying to reach you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell him to hold on. (then, to Joan) First, you assume far more interest in you on my part than exists. I had nothing whatsoever to do with your supposed misfortunes...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MAN TROUBLE - Rev. 4/23/91
